loading and prioritization uh and to do this I'm going to very briefly basically talk
about how the browser prioritizes resources uh and I say very basically because it's actually quite a
complicated process and that would be a whole talk in itself to go into it in detail so very quickly uh in h2p 1
browsers would typic Ally open multiple TCP connections and it would load one
resource at a time so prioritization of resources was based on whatever resources were requested first however
in http2 and HTTP 3 this was changed to a single connection and you could
instead make multiple requests at the same time but that doesn't mean that
every request can be fully responded to at the same time and that's because a
connection is limited in uh how much data it can send so this is particularly
true at the start of a connection as we can only send a limited amount of data for each Network
roundtrip and therefore the server needs to choose which requests it needs to
respond to first as a result the order of this prioritization can have a really big
impact on your web performance because as it prioritizes one thing it's going to deprioritize another so if you send
the JavaScript first your images will be prioritized and vice versa this makes a really big difference
for any any render blocking JavaScript CSS uh that you have because they have
to be downloaded in full before they can be applied and executed furthermore each browser does
it differently it's not the same uh there's a really great post by Robin Marx called HTTP 3 browser HTTP 3
prioritization demystified um it's in my resources it's very very good goes into this in a lot of detail but uh
essentially he talks a lot about how the different browsers prioritize uh different resources and depending on how
you have things set up you might see noticeable differences between like Chrome and Firefox on the performance of
your websites and applications so you know what are we supposed to do about browsers doing
whatever they want well actually we can use fetch
priority for this uh it is a HTML attribute and it allows you to specify
the priority of resources like CSS fonts scripts and images and it allows you to
change that default priority from browsers but it also gives us the opportunity to create that more
consistent Behavior across browsers it has three values High means you want to
prioritize it low means you want to deprioritize it and auto means browser
can do whatever it once unfortunately prioritization is a tad more complicated than three value
vales uh so it's not going to give us the fine grain control that we want uh also
people often assume that if you set it to high it's going to set it to the highest priority and if you set it to
low it's going to set it to the lowest priority but that's not actually the case uh what it actually does is set a
relative priority in relation to the browser's prioritization rules so it's just going to raise or lower the
priority by a set amount it's more like a suggestion to the browser than an
explicit uh rule for example uh this is an example from web.dev so it's Chrome
based uh the Star sheet has the highest priority so if we set a fetch priority
of high it's just going to be the highest priority still if we set it to
low instead of being the highest priority it will be downgraded to a high priority in neither of these scenarios
have we explicitly set at high priority or a low priority it's just raised or
lowered the amount accordingly as another example if we
have an image that has a low priority if we set the fetch priority to high it
will actually set it to high which is great if we set it to low it's just going to retain that low priority so
this is why understanding how each browser uh prioritizes resources can have a really big impact on the
performance because while you might think it's not worth setting low prior here uh for Chrome that may be true but
in another browser it actually might change the priority to create that more consistent Behavior across browsers so
it's handy to know how browsers are doing things in order to best apply these
attributes a really good place that you can use fetch priority is in image carousels which marketing teams love uh
especially at the top of a page affecting that largest contentful paint metric essentially what you can do is
set a fetch Pro of high to the main active image and then set all the others to low and that will prioritize the
first image meaning it'll download quicker meaning it will improve the largest contentful paint metric and then
the other ones will load in once that one has been received and
downloaded so you know this is going to improve performance just by making a
slight change so if you think about other places that you might be able to apply this particular in that largest
contal paint area uh you'll find that things get a bit SN
